column1: The 2012 United States presidential election was the 57th quadrennial presidential election
column2: held on Tuesday
column3: November 6
column4: 2012. The incumbent Democratic President Barack Obama
column5: and his running mate
column6: Vice President Joe Biden
column7: were re-elected to a second term. They defeated the Republican ticket of businessman and former Governor Mitt Romney of Massachusetts and Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin.

column2: Obama secured the Democratic nomination with no serious opposition. The Republicans experienced a competitive primary. Romney was consistently competitive in the polls and won the support of many party leaders
column3: but he faced challenges from a number of more conservative contenders. Romney secured his party's nomination in May
column5: former Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich
column6: and other candidates.

column1: The campaigns focused heavily on domestic issues
column2: and debate centered largely around sound responses to the Great Recession. Other issues included long-term federal budget issues
column3: the future of social insurance programs
column5: Obama's marquee legislative program. Foreign policy was also discussed
column6: including the phase-out of the Iraq War
column9: and appropriate counteractions to terrorism. The campaign was marked by a sharp rise in fundraising
column10: including from nominally independent Super PACs.

column2: winning a majority of both the Electoral College and the popular vote. Obama won 332 electoral votes and 51.1% of the popular vote compared to Romney's 206 electoral votes and 47.2%. Obama was the first incumbent since Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1944 to win reelection with fewer electoral votes and a smaller popular vote margin than had been won in the previous election
column3: and was also the first two-term president since Ronald Reagan to win both his presidential bids with a majority of the nationwide popular vote (50% or more). This was also the first presidential election since 1944 in which neither candidate had military experience. Obama did not hold onto Indiana
column5: or Nebraska's 2nd congressional district
column6: but crucially won all 18 "blue wall" states and defeated Romney in other swing states the Republicans had won in 2000 and 2004
column10: of the nine swing states identified by The Washington Post in the 2012 election

column1: == State changes to voter registration and electoral rules ==

column2: several state legislatures passed new voting laws
column3: especially pertaining to voter identification
column4: with the stated purpose of combating voter fraud; the laws were attacked
column5: however
column6: by the Democratic Party as attempts to suppress voting among its supporters and to improve the Republican Party's presidential prospects. Florida
column10: and West Virginia's state legislatures approved measures to shorten early voting periods. Florida and Iowa barred all felons from voting. Kansas
column13: Texas and Wisconsin state legislatures passed laws requiring voters to have government-issued IDs before they could cast their ballots. This meant
column15: that people without driver's licenses or passports had to gain new forms of ID. Obama
column17: and the Democratic Party fought against many of the new state laws. Former President Bill Clinton denounced them
column19: "There has never been in my lifetime
column20: since we got rid of the poll tax and all the Jim Crow burdens on voting
column21: the determined effort to limit the franchise that we see today". He was referring to Jim Crow laws passed in southern states near the turn of the twentieth century that disenfranchised most blacks from voting and excluded them from the political process for more than six decades. Clinton said the moves would effectively disenfranchise core voter blocs that trend liberal
column24: and Latinos. Rolling Stone magazine criticized the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC) for lobbying in states to bring about these laws
column25: to "solve" a problem that does not exist. The Obama campaign fought against the Ohio law
column26: pushing for a petition and statewide referendum to repeal it in time for the 2012 election.In addition
column27: the Pennsylvania legislature proposed a plan to change its representation in the electoral college from the traditional winner-take-all model to a district-by-district model. As the governorship and both houses of its legislature were Republican-controlled
column28: the move was viewed by some as an attempt to reduce Democratic chances.

column1: With an incumbent president running for re-election against token opposition
column2: the race for the Democratic nomination was largely uneventful. The nomination process consisted of primaries and caucuses
column3: held by the 50 states
column5: Puerto Rico
column6: Washington
column11: high-ranking party members known as superdelegates each received one vote in the convention. A few of the primary challengers surpassed the president's vote total in individual counties in several of the seven contested primaries
column12: though none made a significant impact in the delegate count. Running unopposed everywhere else
column13: President Obama cemented his status as the Democratic presumptive nominee on April 3
column15: by securing the minimum number of pledged delegates needed to obtain the nomination.

column1: Due to a number of scandals

column14: and Romney won only in New Hampshire.

column1: A number of candidates dropped out at this point in the nomination process. Bachmann withdrew after finishing sixth in the Iowa caucuses
column2: Huntsman withdrew after coming in third in New Hampshire
column3: and Perry withdrew when polls showed him drawing low numbers in South Carolina.

column2: who had previously run an essentially one-state campaign in Iowa
column3: was able to organize a national campaign after his surprising victory there. He unexpectedly carried three states in a row on February 7 and overtook Romney in nationwide opinion polls

column5: Romney won all of the other contests between South Carolina and the Super Tuesday primaries
column6: and regained his first-place status in nationwide opinion polls by the end of February.

column1: The Super Tuesday primaries took place on March 6. Romney carried six states

column3: and Gingrich won only in his home state of Georgia. Throughout the rest of March
column5: including the territorial contests and the first local conventions that allocated delegates (Wyoming's county conventions). Santorum won Kansas and three Southern primaries

column7: who became a formidable frontrunner after securing more than half of the delegates allocated in March.

column9: Gingrich dropped out on May 2 in a move that was seen as an effective end to the nomination contest. After Gingrich's spokesman announced his upcoming withdrawal

column11: but he stopped campaigning on May 14 to focus on state conventions.

column1: The United States presidential election of 2012 broke new records in financing
column2: fundraising
column3: and negative campaigning. Through grassroots campaign contributions
column5: and Super PACs
column6: Obama and Romney raised a combined total of more than $2 billion. Super PACs constituted nearly one-fourth of the total financing
column7: with most coming from pro-Romney PACs. Obama raised $690 million through online channels
column8: beating his record of $500 million in 2008. Most of the advertising in the 2012 presidential campaign was decidedly negative—80% of Obama's ads and 84% of Romney's ads were negative. The tax-exempt non-profit Americans for Prosperity
column11: a political advocacy group that is not a political action committee or super-PAC
column12: ran a television advertising campaign opposing Obama described by The Washington Post as "early and relentless". Americans for Prosperity spent $8.4 million in swing states on television advertisements denouncing the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 loan guarantee to Solyndra
column13: a manufacturer of solar panels that went bankrupt
column14: an advertising campaign described by The Wall Street Journal in November 2011 as "perhaps the biggest attack on Mr. Obama so far".

column2: phrases
column3: and statements ===

column1: Severely conservative – In a speech he made at the Conservative Political Action Conference in February 2012
column2: Romney claimed that he had been a "severely conservative Republican governor". Romney's description of his record as "severely conservative" was widely criticized by political commentators as both rhetorically clumsy and factually inaccurate. Later
column3: the phrase "severely conservative" was frequently brought up by Democrats to make fun of Romney's willingness to associate himself with the far-right of the Republican Party as well as his apparent lack of sincerity while doing so. Conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh
column4: who played the clip on his radio show
column5: said: "I have never heard anybody say
column6: 'I'm severely conservative.' "

column1: You didn't build that – A portion of a statement that Obama made in a July 2012 campaign speech in Roanoke
column2: Virginia. Obama said that businesses depend on government-provided infrastructure to succeed
column3: but critics of his remarks argued that he was underplaying the work of entrepreneurs and giving the government credit for individuals' success. The Romney campaign immediately jumped on the statement in an effort to drive a wedge between Obama and small business owners/employees. A major theme of the 2012 Republican National Convention was "We Built It".

column1: 47 percent – An expression Romney used at a private campaign fundraising event
column2: which was secretly recorded and publicly released. At the private event
column3: Romney said that 47 percent of the people would vote for Barack Obama no matter what Romney said or did because those people "...are dependent upon government... I'll never convince them they should take personal responsibility and care for their lives".

column1: Binders full of women – A phrase that Romney used in the second presidential debate to refer to the long list of female candidates that he considered when choosing his cabinet members as Governor of Massachusetts.
Horses and bayonets – After Romney said in the third presidential debate that the U.S. Navy was smaller than at any time since 1917
column2: Obama replied
column3: "We have fewer ships than we did in 1916. Well
column5: we also have fewer horses and bayonets
column6: because the nature of our military's changed."

column1: Shovel-ready jobs – a phrase used to describe some stimulus projects promoted by the administration. During the debate on September 23
column3: Gary Johnson quipped
column4: "My next-door neighbor's two dogs have created more shovel-ready jobs than this president."

column1: Romnesia – A term coined by a blogger in April 2011 and used by Obama late in the campaign to describe Romney's alleged inability to take responsibility for his past statements.

column2: 000 bet – During a Republican debate
column3: Romney facetiously bet Texas governor Rick Perry $10
column4: 000 that he (Perry) was wrong about Romney's position on the individual mandate under the Affordable Healthcare Act. The statement was vilified by Democrats as exemplary of Romney being out of touch with the average American.

column1: Romneyshambles – a phrase used by the British press after Romney criticized British preparations for the 2012 Summer Olympics
column2: which was a play on omnishambles. The phrase became a popular hashtag on Twitter and was later chosen as one of Collins English Dictionary's words of the year.

column1: On the day of the election
column2: spread betting firm Spreadex were offering an Obama Electoral College Votes spread of 296-300 to Romney's 239-243. In reality Obama's victory over Romney was far greater
column3: winning 332 electoral votes to Romney's 206. Romney lost all but one of nine battleground states and received 47 percent of the nationwide popular vote to Obama's 51 percent.Popular vote totals are from the official Federal Election Commission report. The results of the electoral vote were certified by Congress on January 4

column1: Foreign leaders reacted with both positive and mixed messages. Most world leaders congratulated and praised Barack Obama on his re-election victory. However
column2: Venezuela and some other states had tempered reactions. Pakistan commented that Romney's defeat had made Pakistan-United States relations safer. Stock markets fell noticeably after Obama's re-election
column3: with the Dow Jones Industrial Average
column5: and the S&P 500 each declining over two percent the day after the election.

column1: The United States has a population of 50 million Hispanic and Latino Americans
column2: 27 million of whom are citizens eligible to vote (13% of total eligible voters). Traditionally
column3: only half of eligible Hispanic voters vote (around 7% of voters); of them
column4: 71% voted for Barack Obama (increasing his percentage of the vote by 5%); therefore
column5: the Hispanic vote was an important factor in Obama's re-election
column6: since the vote difference between the two main parties was only 3.9%Exit polls were conducted by Edison Research of Somerville

column1: Combined with the re-elections of Bill Clinton and George W. Bush
column2: Obama's victory in the 2012 election marked only the second time in American history that three consecutive presidents were each elected to two or more full terms (the first time being the consecutive two-term presidencies of Thomas Jefferson
column3: James Madison
column4: and James Monroe). This was also the first election since 1944 in which neither of the major candidates had any military experience.The 2012 election marked the first time since Franklin D. Roosevelt's last two re-elections in 1940 and 1944 that a Democratic presidential candidate won a majority of the popular vote in two consecutive elections. Obama was also the first president of either party to secure at least 51% of the popular vote in two elections since Dwight Eisenhower in 1952 and 1956. Obama is the third Democratic president to secure at least 51% of the vote twice
column5: after Andrew Jackson and Franklin D. Roosevelt.  Romney won the popular vote in 226 congressional districts making this the first time since 1960 that the winner of the election did not win the popular vote in a majority of the  congressional districts. Romney also became the first Republican since Gerald Ford's narrow defeat to Jimmy Carter
column7: to fail to win a presidential election while earning a minimum of 200 electoral votes.

column1: Romney lost his home state of Massachusetts
column2: becoming the first major party presidential candidate to lose his home state since Democrat Al Gore lost his home state of Tennessee to Republican George W. Bush in the 2000 election. Romney lost his home state by more than 23%
column3: the worst losing margin for a major party candidate since John Frémont in 1856. Even worse than Frémont
column4: Romney failed to win a single county in his home state. In addition
column5: since Obama carried Ryan's home state of Wisconsin
column6: the Romney–Ryan ticket was the first major party ticket since the 1972 election to have both of its nominees lose their home states. Romney won the popular vote in every county of three states: Utah
column8: and West Virginia; Obama did so in four states: Vermont
column11: and Hawaii.Romney's loss prompted the Republican National Committee to try to appeal to the American Latino population by concentrating on different approaches to immigration.  These were short-lived due to activity and anger from the Republican base and may have contributed to the selection of Donald Trump as their presidential candidate four years later.Gary Johnson's popular vote total set a Libertarian Party record
column12: and his popular vote percentage was the second-best showing for a Libertarian in a presidential election
column13: trailing only Ed Clark's in 1980. Johnson would go on to beat this record in the 2016 presidential election
column14: winning the most votes for the Libertarian ticket in history. At the time
column15: Green Party candidate Jill Stein's popular vote total made her the most successful female presidential candidate in a general election in United States history. This was later surpassed by Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election.

column1: Obama's vote total was the second most votes received in the history of presidential elections (only behind Obama's 2008 victory which was the all-time record for most votes in a single election) and the most ever for a reelected president. However
column2: Obama also became the first president in American history to be reelected to a second term by smaller margins in every way possible: Compared to his victory in 2008
column3: he won fewer states (28 to 26)
column5: fewer popular votes (69.5 million to 65.9 million)
column6: a smaller percentage of the popular vote (52.9% to 51.1%)
column7: and fewer congressional districts (242 to 209).The 2012 election marked the first time since 1988 in which no state was won by a candidate with a plurality of the state's popular vote. All states were won with over 50% of the vote.
